author: agonzalezm
body:
I am using microsoft.PowerShell.SDK from net core 3.1  to run PS command, it works fine in windows 10 but in windows 8.1 I get this error:

Is there any workaround to this and to be able to run PS in same way without updating powershell to 5.1?

Detected Windows PowerShell version 4.0. Windows PowerShell 5.1 is required to load modules using Windows PowerShell compatibility feature. Install Windows Management Framework (WMF) 5.1 from https://aka.ms/WMF5Download to enable this feature. ---    at Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportModuleCommand.ImportModulesUsingWinCompat(IEnumerable`1 moduleNames, IEnumerable`1 moduleFullyQualifiedNames, ImportModuleOptions importModuleOptions)   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleCmdletBase.LoadModuleManifest(String moduleManifestPath, ExternalScriptInfo manifestScriptInfo, Hashtable data, Hashtable localizedData, ManifestProcessingFlags manifestProcessingFlags, Version minimumVersion, Version maximumVersion, Version requiredVersion, Nullable`1 requiredModuleGuid, ImportModuleOptions& options, Boolean& containedErrors)   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleCmdletBase.LoadModuleManifest(ExternalScriptInfo scriptInfo, ManifestProcessingFlags manifestProcessingFlags, Version minimumVersion, Version maximumVersion, Version requiredVersion, Nullable`1 requiredModuleGuid, ImportModuleOptions& options)   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleCmdletBase.LoadModule(PSModuleInfo parentModule, String fileName, String moduleBase, String prefix, SessionState ss, Object privateData, ImportModuleOptions& options, ManifestProcessingFlags manifestProcessingFlags, Boolean& found, Boolean& moduleFileFound)   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleCmdletBase.LoadUsingExtensions(PSModuleInfo parentModule, String moduleName, String fileBaseName, String extension, String moduleBase, String prefix, SessionState ss, ImportModuleOptions options,

comments.author: agonzalezm
vexx32
comments.body:
The error is just effectively stating that the WinPS compatibility remoting won't be available, but it shouldn't impact general usage of PowerShell apart from the error being reported. I'm not sure if there's a way to set it to be ignored completely though.

/cc @adityapatwardhan

comments.author: agonzalezm
comments.body: But i am not using powershell remoting, i just want to run a local script in the local machine and it is failing to do so.

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: @agonzalezm What's in the script? Does it contain a command only available on Windows PowerShell?

comments.author: agonzalezm
comments.body:
@SeeminglyScience  yes it runs powershell command Get-MpThreat from defender, running that on powershell console works fine.

psh.Execute("Set-ExecutionPolicy bypass -force -confirm:$false; Import-Module defender;  Get-MpThreat | select-object -property CategoryID,SeverityID, ThreatID, ThreatName | convertto-json", 60))

comments.author: adityapatwardhan
comments.body: I will have a look at this sometime this week. Thanks for reporting this.

comments.author: adityapatwardhan
comments.body: Sorry I was busy last week with Preview.5 release. I will have a look this week.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
> Detected Windows PowerShell version 4.0. Windows PowerShell 5.1 is required to load modules using Windows PowerShell compatibility feature. Install Windows Management Framework (WMF) 5.1 from https://aka.ms/WMF5Download to enable this feature. @agonzalezm This error message indicates that the `Defender` module is not compatible with PS 7. The `Defender` module on Windows 10 is compatible with PS 7 -- `Depender.psd1` has `CompatiblePSEditions = @('Desktop', 'Core')`, but I don't think the module on Windows 8.1 has this compatibility. Therefore, PS 7 needs to load it using the [Windows PowerShell Compatibility feature](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_windows_powershell_compatibility?view=powershell-7), which requires Windows PowerShell 5.1 and won't work with Windows PowerShell 4.0. One workaround is to run `Import-Module Defender -SkipEditionCheck`. `-SkipEditionCheck` will force to load an incompatible module without going through the Windows PowerShell Compatibility feature. It may not work if the module just simply doesn't work in .NET Core, so you have to try it out.
Microsoft Download Center
WMF 5.1
Windows Management Framework 5.1 includes updates to Windows PowerShell, Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC), Windows Remote Management (WinRM), Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI). Release notes: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=839460

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

title: Run PS from net core using microsoft.PowerShell.SDK in windows 8.1 failure
